III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Privacy safeguard
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12211
Section (1) An agency shall safeguard the privacy of a child and his or her
Description family.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Worker is no longer assigned to case but has had contact and
shared case information with the foster parent and birth parent.
Investigation On 4/23/25 anonymous Complainant reported some concerns
regarding a DHHS Worker for Youth A’s foster care case.
Complainant indicated the case moved from the former worker,
DHHS Worker to a private agency on 3/31/25. However, DHHS
Worker continued to have contact with Foster Parent 1, Foster
Parent 2 and Parent. Complainant stated there was recently a
special evaluation conducted on the foster home. When the
allegation came in, DHHS Worker contacted Foster Parent 1 and
asked, “What’s going on?” DHHS Worker also continued contact
with Parent, despite rights being terminated. DHHS Worker
contacted Parent because Parent posted a photo of Youth A on
her Facebook page. During that conversation, DHHS Worker gave
Parent information about Youth A’s respite placement. This
prompted Parent to reach out to Youth A online and attempt to
speak with her. It was reported DHHS Worker also told Parent
what city Youth A was residing in with the foster parents.
Complainant was contacted by phone on 4/24/25 and declined an
interview. However, they were able to send screen shots of
Facebook and text communications referenced in the allegations.
Complainant was informed the investigation would focus on the
three main concerns as they related to licensing rules: DHHS
Worker contact foster parent about investigation, DHHS Worker
contact with Parent about Youth A being in respite, and DHHS
Worker informed Parent of location of Youth A’s foster home.
Interviews:
DHHS Worker was interviewed via video call on Teams on
4/30/25. DHHS Worker reported being assigned to Youth A’s case
for approximately two years, before it moved to another agency on
3/31/25. Youth A became an MCI ward on 2/27/25 and the case
moved to a private agency to complete the adoption process.
DHHS Worker recalled Foster Care Worker reached out to her on
2

4/10/25 or 4/11/25 while they were completing a home visit and
stated Youth A reported she did not feel loved by the foster
parents and made some allegations about them making her feel
uncomfortable. DHHS Worker told Foster Care Worker that she
had never heard statements like that from Youth A before and was
surprised by the allegations. DHHS Worker stated she did not
discuss the allegations with Foster Parent 1 or Foster Parent 2.
However, Foster Parent 1 reached out to DHHS Worker and
stated she did not know what to do about Youth A’s lying, and the
situation was affecting Foster Parent 1’s health, indicating they
were not sure if they would continue the plan to adopt. DHHS
Worker decided to speak with Youth A, as she had worked with
the youth for about two years and wanted to know she was safe.
DHHS Worker also wanted to try to help preserve the placement
and have an honest conversation with Youth A about her ongoing
behavior. DHHS Worker indicated she did not think Youth A would
open up to the new worker, as the case had only transferred about
ten days prior. Youth A told DHHS Worker she made up the
allegations as she was frustrated about being grounded. DHHS
Worker encouraged Youth A to be honest with her new worker
and talk about the situation. DHHS Worker also told the foster
parents Youth A was feeling frustrated and encouraged
conversation. DHHS Worker stated she never discussed the
allegations with the foster parents as she knew it was not her job
to investigate.
On 4/10/25 Foster Parent 2 contacted DHHS Worker via text to
ask about setting up respite. DHHS Worker replied to Foster
Parent 2 that Foster Care Worker would need to arrange respite.
DHHS Worker did not know any details about when the respite
occurred, where, or for how long. DHHS Worker denied telling
Parent anything about respite. However, DHHS Worker reported
she had some contact with Parent around that time. On 4/12/25
Foster Parent 2 texted DHHS Worker that Parent had posted an
updated photo of Youth A on Facebook, and they were unsure
how Parent got the photo. On 4/12/25 Foster Parent 1 texted
DHHS Worker that Parent continued trying to call Youth A through
Facebook Messenger. This was a situation that had been
occurring prior to case transfer and Foster Parent 1 was letting
DHHS Worker know that it was continuing. DHHS Worker called
Parent and let her know that she was aware of the attempted
calls, and that it was inappropriate as rights were terminated and
there was a no-contact order. During the call DHHS Worker tried
to dissuade Parent from calling again, by stating Youth A was not
at the house that weekend anyway and could not be reached.
DHHS Worker believed this may be why Parent mentioned respite
3

in one of her Facebook messages to Youth A. DHHS Worker
stated she did not say anything about where Youth A was, or why
she was not at the foster home. DHHS Worker told Parent that
she was no longer involved in the case and did not have any
information, nor could she share it anyway. On 4/12/25 DHHS
Worker agreed with Foster Parent 1 via text that the new worker,
Foster Care Worker, should be notified of Parent’s continued
attempts to contact Youth A.
Regarding the foster parent’s location, DHHS Worker stated she
never gave Parent information about the location of the foster
home. However, when DHHS Worker had the case, Parent knew
what school Youth A was attending, as this was a known fact
when the case was in reunification. Therefore, it seemed logical
that Parent knew what city Youth A was residing in with the foster
parents. In addition, as this is a relative placement in the same
community as other family members, it is possible other family
members may have shared the information as well. DHHS Worker
stated there were definitely some communication issues at the
beginning when the case transferred. DHHS Worker did her best
to refer foster parents back to Foster Care Worker. However,
Parent never had contact with Foster Care Worker, as her rights
had already been terminated when the case transferred. DHHS
Worker believed she could get through to Parent about ceasing
the Facebook contact, based on the fact she worked with her for
so long, and the no-contact order occurred while she had the
case. DHHS Worker stated she had no intention of interfering with
the case or being involved after the case transferred.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via video call on
Teams, on 5/13/25. FCW was informed of the allegations. FCW
confirmed Foster Parent 1 is the paternal aunt of Youth A. Foster
Parent 1 told FCW that she was frustrated DHHS Worker gave
Parent information about them. Foster Parent 1 stated that DHHS
Worker had contact with Parent to tell her not to contact Youth A.
Foster Parent 1 believed DHHS Worker must have shared
information with Parent at that time about where they live and
Youth A going to respite. FCW never addressed these concerns
with DHHS Worker. FCW stated she never spoke with Parent
about contacting Youth A on Facebook. FCW received the case
after parental rights were terminated, therefore she never
established contact with Parent. Regarding Youth A going to
respite, FCW reported DHHS Worker may have become aware of
the respite placement during a case conference, as respite
occurred the next day. FCW did not believe Foster Parent 1
shared any information about respite with DHHS Worker. Foster
4

Parent 1 indicated that messages on Facebook made her believe
that DHHS Worker told Parent about respite.
Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 were interviewed jointly by
phone on 5/29/25. The foster parents reported they were relative
caregivers for Youth A. Foster Parent 1 stated, with Foster Parent
2’s agreement, that they really liked DHHS Worker and thought
she did a great job with the case. They did not feel she was too
involved with anything. It was just recently that they found
Facebook messages from Parent, indicating that DHHS Worker
told her what city they lived in, and that Youth A was at a respite
placement for a weekend in April. The foster parents did not have
any indication that DHHS Worker told Parent where the respite
placement was. However, the foster parents were concerned that
if Parent knew where they lived, she would show up at their
house, which would be traumatizing to Youth A. Foster Parent 1
stated Parent’s mother lived only five minutes away from them.
Therefore, it was a very real concern that Parent would find their
home or run into them in public.
Foster Parent 1 stated Parent had attempted to contact Youth A
on Facebook before and after case transfer. After the case
transferred, the foster parents noticed some messenger activity on
Youth A’s Facebook account. They saw Youth A had contact with
Parent. Foster Parent 1 stated they did not know the new case
worker (Foster Care Worker) yet, as the case had just transferred,
so Foster Parent 1 reached out to DHHS Worker to let her know
that Parent had posted a newer photo of Youth A on her
Facebook page. DHHS Worker then reached out to Parent, to let
her know she could not contact Youth A. Foster Parent 1 stated
she was upset that Parent knew what city they lived in and what
school Youth A attended. The school was aware of rights being
terminated and reported to Foster Parent 1 that Parent had tried to
contact the school to get information about Youth A.
Regarding DHHS Worker discussing an investigation with the
foster parents, both foster parents stated they never had a special
evaluation or discussed allegations with anyone. Foster Parent 1
stated that she had contact with DHHS Worker when she was
frustrated with Youth A’s behavior. DHHS Worker spoke with
Youth A to try to help with their concerns. This occurred as the
case was transitioning to the new agency and Foster Parent 1 felt
more comfortable speaking with DHHS Worker as she had not
met Foster Care Worker yet.
5

DHHS Supervisor was interviewed via video call on Teams on
5/30/25. Supervisor confirmed he supervised DHHS Worker for
the past year, while she had Youth A’s case. The case then
transferred to another agency on 3/31/25, to complete the
adoption with Youth A’s relative caregiver. Supervisor reported
DHHS Worker was very good at her job and there were no
concerns. DHHS Worker did not have an overly friendly, or close
relationship with Parent. Parent had significant mental health and
substance abuse concerns, which made the case very
challenging, but DHHS Worker worked well with her.
Regarding the allegations, Supervisor indicated he had no reason
to believe DHHS Worker shared any information with Parent about
the location of the foster home or respite placement. Parent was
aware of the school Youth A attended as that information was not
protected when the case was in reunification. Supervisor noted
that having relative caregivers can be difficult as family members
share information, especially when they live in the same
community. Supervisor had no knowledge of DHHS Worker
discussing the respite placement with Parent. Supervisor also had
no knowledge of DHHS Worker discussing a special evaluation
with the foster parents after the case transferred.
Overall, Supervisor stated that DHHS Worker was a great worker
who always did the right thing in his experience. He would be
surprised by any slip-ups, but understands we are all human and
this may be a coachable moment if a problem is found.
Attempts were made to interview Parent on 6/2/25 and 6/9/25.
However, there was no response.
Documents Review:
• Record for Foster Parent 1 & Foster Parent 2- Unlicensed
relative caregiver for Youth A since 4/2/24. No special
evaluations, as they were not licensed. The family lived at
the current address prior to accepting placement of Youth
A.
• Youth A’s case record: MCI ward 2/27/25. TDM occurred
3/14/25 for case transfer. Case transfer effective 3/31/25.
• 3/29/25 text from Foster Parent 1 to DHHS Worker: “Good
Morning! So I don’t know who to contact with this info.
(Parent) called (Youth A) again yesterday. It was a missed
call thank goodness. I saw it late last night.”
• 3/29/25 text from DHHS Worker to Foster Parent 1: “I think
we need to let the court know. Let me see if there is a
motion for noncompliance that can be started. I told
6

(Parent) last week that any contact is contempt of court and
she can be charged. Or we could just call the police and file
charges”.
• 3/29/25 text from Foster Parent 1 to DHHS Worker: “Can
we do both or is one as good as the other?”
• 3/30/25 text from DHHS Worker to Foster Parent 1: “Sorry,
I didn’t answer this. Let me see if I can find out which route
we should take.”
• 3/30/25 text from Foster Parent 1 to DHHS Worker:
“Attached screen shot of FB missed call and message from
(Parent).”
o Screenshot- 3/29/25 11:00 am message from Parent
to Foster Parent 1 “Hiiii”
o Screenshot- 3/29/25 9:41pm message from Foster
Parent 1 to Parent: “you need to stop with the
contact. You are prohibited from having any contact
with (Youth A) and you and I are not friends. I will
not be communicating with you at all. Let (Youth A)
have a chance at a good, normal life for a change.
You should be concentrating on getting yourself
together. Leave us alone!”
• Facebook Messenger messages:
o 4/8/25 from Parent to Youth A: “(DHHS Worker) told
me that (Foster Parent 1) had to get a place in
Hudsonville… Is that where you are?” Youth A
responded “yeah”. Parent said, “call me quick”.
o 4/11/25 three attempted calls from Parent to Youth
A. Then a message, “Hi my sweet (Youth A) I hope
you’re OK. I don’t know if this will get to you but I
kinda heard a bit of what happened and that you’re
not there right now. If you need me I’m here…”
• 4/10/25 text from Foster Parent 2 to DHHS Worker: “Good
morning. Are you still who we contact if we need to request
a respite weekend?”
• 4/10/25 text from DHHS Worker to Foster Parent 2: “Has
the new worker been in touch with you? You’d ask her now”
• 4/12/25 text from Foster Parent 1 to DHHS Worker: “She
(Parent) just called again”. “Now that I think about it, the
bigger problems began with us finding out (Youth A)
contacted (Parent).”
• 4/12/25 text from DHHS Worker to Foster Parent 1: “I
called (Parent) regarding the new picture I found on her FB
page of (Youth A). She said it was an old one. I asked
(Parent) if (Youth A) had contacted her and she said no. All
I told her was (Youth A) was at another house for the
7

weekend and nothing more. (Parent) really needs to stop
the contact. I’m so sorry all of this is happening.”
• 4/12/25 text from Foste Parent 1 to DHHS Worker: “Do I
talk to (Foster Care Worker) about all of this then? I’m not
sure how much further I can take all of this. Like I said it’s
starting to affect my heath in a negative way.”
Analysis No violation was found. Based on interviews with the current and
former caseworker and foster parents, it did not appear DHHS
Worker was openly sharing case information. Parent was aware of
the community the youth lived in, due to education information that
was available while the case was in reunification. In addition, it
appeared DHHS Worker made a generalized statement about the
youth not being home, and there was no indication they provided
detailed information about the respite. Lastly, there was no
indication DHHS Worker was inappropriately involved in an
investigation as there was not a special evaluation on the foster
home.
CONSULTATION:
Based on interviews, the foster parents’ initiated contact with
DHHS Worker for a few days after the case transfer date. DHHS
Worker redirected the foster parents but also tried to provide
support by talking with Foster Parent 1 and Youth A. DHHS
Worker also reached out to Parent to remind them of a court order
that occurred while she had the case. While DHHS Worker
appeared to be well intentioned, best practice would be to redirect
any case participants to the assigned worker and contact the new
agency to discuss any issues or develop a plan which may or may
not include assistance from the former worker.
In addition, the agency was advised that a case conference may
be beneficial to define roles and provide contact information to
foster parents before a case transfers.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
8

Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
